title: Reading Comprehension: Analyzing Nonfiction Texts

vocab.definition: The most important point or central message of a text
Facts, examples, or explanations that support the main idea
A conclusion reached using evidence and reasoning
The reason why an author wrote a text: to inform, persuade, or entertain
How information is organized in a text, such as cause-and-effect or compare-contrast

teachingNotes: Use current events and science articles. Practice identifying different text structures. Teach students to distinguish between facts and opinions in nonfiction.

sample.question: What is the most important point of a text called?
A conclusion using evidence is an ________.
Facts that support the main idea are ________ details.
The reason an author writes is the author's ________.
How information is organized is the text ________.
Make an inference: The ground is wet. What likely happened?

truefalse.question: An inference is a conclusion you reach using evidence and reasoning.
The main idea is always stated in the first sentence.
Supporting details help explain the main idea.
All nonfiction texts are organized the same way.
An author's purpose can be to inform, persuade, or entertain.
Text structure never matters in nonfiction.
Cause-and-effect is a type of text structure.
Supporting details include facts and examples.
The main idea and supporting details are unrelated.

multiplechoice.question: If an author writes to convince you of something, what is their purpose?

choices: It rained, so the ground is wet.
expectedAny: it rained, so the ground is wet

shortanswer.question: What are three common ways authors organize nonfiction texts?
Explain what an inference is.
expectedAny: a conclusion drawn from text clues

shortanswer.question: Give an example of a supporting detail for: 'Dogs make great pets.'
What is the difference between main idea and supporting details?
expectedAny: main idea is the central point
supporting details explain the main idea
main idea is what it's about
details prove or explain the main idea
main idea = big idea; details = proof/examples

shortanswer.question: Name the three main author's purposes.
expectedAny: to inform, to persuade, to entertain

shortanswer.question: How does text structure help readers?
expectedAny: guides expectations for how ideas unfold

shortanswer.question: Give an example of cause-and-effect.
expectedAny: it rained so the ground is wet
she ate too much so felt sick
I watered plants so they grew

shortanswer.question: What clues help you identify the main idea?
Make an inference: The dog is barking and wagging its tail. How does it feel?
Why are supporting details important?
expectedAny: they back up the main idea
